text.text: No tube station? No problem. Crouch End's London Underground isolation has given it a proper little community feel which we're all about. You've got loads of independent cafes, some art galleries, a recording studio, plus one of the biggest music stars of all time popped in for some jerk chicken once. Right on.
Best for... kicking back with a coffee

tip.text: Quaint without being cutesy-poo, Coffee Circus feels like an old tearoom with chintzy wallpaper, rickety furniture and the occasional live music set. During the week they stick to serving awesome gluten-free cakes and pastries, and on the weekend the kitchen opens for simple brunch dishes. See the photography on the walls here? They're up for sale if you're in the market for some good snaps.

text.text: Quaint without being cutesy-poo, Coffee Circus feels like an old tearoom with chintzy wallpaper, rickety furniture and the occasional live music set. During the week they stick to serving awesome gluten-free cakes and pastries, and on the weekend the kitchen opens for simple brunch dishes.

tip.text:
Banner's is Crouch End royalty. People sometimes mistake its colourful paint job for a Jamaican restaurant...well, they're half right, because the jerk chicken draws folks from miles around. Bob Dylan wouldn't eat at just any old place. Oh you didn't know? Bob himself came in here to chow down a few years back – they have a plaque and memorabilia over his table to mark the occasion.

There's everything from Thai to Greek on the menu, and the world beers and cocktails coming from the bar make this family-friendly restaurant one giant international potluck party.

text.text: Banner's is Crouch End royalty. People sometimes mistake its colourful paint job for a Jamaican restaurant...well, they're half right, because the jerk chicken draws folks from miles around. Even little know singer Bob Dylan has chowed down here in the past (or so we're told). There's everything from Thai to Greek on the menu, and the world beers and cocktails coming from the bar make this family-friendly restaurant one giant international potluck party.
Best for... watching the big screen

tip.text: A few years back, some adventurous locals spotted an old Salvation Army quarters lying dormant and decided to give it a lil' makeover. The result is ArtHouse Crouch End, a communal art hub that puts on all sorts across their two screens including recent releases, live streams of NT productions, music, discussions, dance and comedy. It's all things to all CrouchEnders, a real local hero.

text.text: Forget Vue's sticky floors and arse-numbing seats, this is the spot if you want to catch a flick. Inside an old Salvation Army quarters, this community run cinema has an excellently curated bill of arty and indie films along with special treats such as director Q&A's. With a nice lil' cafe and bar to boot, this is pretty much what all cinemas should be.

tip.text:
Don't believe the lies of some gastropubs – 'Modern British' doesn't mean gourmet fish and chips or a seasonal risotto. The guys at Heirloom show us what Brits are truly capable of in the kitchen.

Every Wednesday the menu changes, with top quality meat and game being specialities, supplied from Vickers (who also supply the Ledbury). Don't think they scrimp on the veg though – they actually own their own farm in Chesham, and grow almost everything they use. They've also carefully picked out a range of bio-dynamic wines too. This place really sticks it to the folks who say the Brits don't know food.

text.text: Despite what gastropubs are trying to have us believe, modern British is much more than gourmet fish and chips, and the guys at Heirloom are showing us what we're really capable of. Every Wednesday the menu changes, with top quality meat and game being specialities, supplied from Vickers whilst their veg comes from their own farm in Chesham. They've also carefully picked out a range of bio-dynamic wines too.
Best for... getting your tapas on

tip.text:
Barcelona, meet Brooklyn. Brooklyn, say hi to Barcelona. This tapas bar has all the good grub of sunny Spain, mixed with the style of our New York buds across the pond. Think exposed brick, stripped wooden floors, all that jazz.

The bull's head 'strength test' machine at the front door is a bit weird, but if you beat it you get a free cocktail. Food-wise, the Crispy Pork Belly here is our pick, along with the Salt Cod Croquettes. All the Spanish wines are right on, but we recommend going for one of their sherries – it's not just for cooking.

text.text: Barcelona, meet Brooklyn. Brooklyn, say hi to Barcelona. This tapas bar has all the good grub of sunny Spain, mixed with the style of our New York buds across the pond. Think exposed brick, stripped wooden floors, all that jazz. The Crispy Pork Belly here is our pick, along with the Salt Cod Croquettes. Also definitely get into some of their Spanish wine.

tip.text: A few years back, this boozer used to be a bit rough and ready. Now, you can't keep us away. Come here on a quiz night and one of the rounds has all the teams making tin foil or lego sculptures for points. Movie nights are a great draw, and the staff also have some serious playlist skills. The vibe here is just always bang on what a London pub should be.

text.text: A few years back, this boozer used to be a bit rough and ready. Now, you can't keep us away. Come here on a quiz night and one of the rounds has all the teams making tin foil or lego sculptures for points. Movie nights are a great draw, and the staff also have some serious playlist skills. The vibe here is just always bang on what a London pub should be.

tip.text: Park Road Lido has been a Crouch End watering hole since 1926, but pools aren't one of those places where 'old school' is much of a selling point so you'll be glad to know they've had a recent refurb. The place is now a 50x23m heated outdoor pool - the largest in London according to them. As much as we love a splash about, we're equally into chilling in the sun and the grassy bank and sun loungers here are perfect for such frivolity.

text.text: It's Crouch End. A recently renovated 50m lido. The water is heated. There's a sauna. It's open all year round. What else is there? Well the building is a bit dilapidated and the actual running of this place can be a bit of a shitshow, so you will want to avoid on busy days if at all possible.
